StringWithMarkup.String: AQUATIC FATE: When benz(a)anthracene is released into water it will rapidly sorb to the sediment and particulate matter in the water column including phytoplankton and zooplankton. Therefore, high initial concentrations are rapidly reduced (few hours). However low concentrations caused by desorption can last almost indefinitely(1). The dissolved benz(a)anthracene will undergo photolysis (half-life hours to a few days) and in eutrophic bodies of water, oxidation by alkylperoxy radicals may be important. The relative contribution of sorption and photolysis to benz(a)anthracene removal will depend on the type of aquatic system(4). In a microcosm experiment which simulated shallow coastal waters of the northeast US, 29 percent of the benz(a)anthracene had respired to CO2 while 21 percent was unchanged(2). When a crude oil dispersion was placed on top of a water column in a controlled ecosystem enclosure in Saanich Inlet, Canada, the benz(a)anthracene concentration in the water column decreased exponentially, declining to half its initial concentration in 4 to 5 days(3). Another study determined a half-life for benz(a)anthracene of 290 days in sediment from an oil-contaminated stream but a half-life of 10 to 400 times as long in an uncontaminated stream(5). Benz(a)anthracene was found to absorb light beyond 480 nm and photolyze in sunlight(6). The photolysis half-life of benz(a)anthracene in water measured in early March at 40 N latitude was determined to be 5 hours(6). Another investigator estimated that the midsummer photolysis half-life for benz(a)anthracene was 0.6 hours(4). The photolysis rate for benz(a)anthracene was reduced in humic waters due to light screening and quenching. Photolysis was also inhibited in anaerobic waters. In addition, 7,12-benzanthracene quinone and 2 unidentified products were observed in aerobic waters(6). When modeled for various environmental systems, the photolysis half-life of benz(a)anthracene was 10 hours for an oligotrophic lake, 20 hours for a stream and 50 hours for a eutrophic pond or lake(1). Although the rate of loss due to oxidation by peroxyl radicals is about four times slower than for photolysis, this process is dominant in a eutrophic lake or pond (half-life of 38 hours)(6). In an experiment in which crude oil was added to a large salt-water tank with simulated natural conditions, 55 percent of the benz(a)anthracene photo-decomposed in 5 hours and 100 percent photo-decomposed in 10 hours(7).

Reference: (1) Bidleman TF; Environ Sci Technol 22: 361-367 (1988)
(2) Sonnefield WJ et al; Anal Chem 55: 275-80 (1983)
(3) Meylan WM, Howard PH; Chemosphere 26: 2293-99 (1993)
(4) Freitag D et al; Chemosphere 14: 1589-1616 (1985)
(5) Baum EJ; pp. 45-70 in Polycyclic Hydrocarbons and Cancer Vol 1 Geboin HV, Tsu Pop, Eds. Academic Press (1978)
(6) Lunde G, Bjoerseth A; Nature 268: 518-9 (1977)

StringWithMarkup.String: ATMOSPHERIC FATE: According to a model of gas/particle partitioning of semivolatile organic compounds in the atmosphere(1), Benz(a)anthracene, which has an experimental vapor pressure of 2.1X10-7 mm Hg at 25 °C(2), will exist in both the vapor and particulate phases in the ambient atmosphere. Vapor-phase benz(a)anthracene is degraded in the atmosphere by reaction with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals(SRC); the half-life for this reaction in air is estimated to be about 8 hours(SRC)calculated from its rate constant of 5X10-11 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(SRC) that was derived using a structure estimation method(3). Particulate-phase benz(a)anthracene may be physically removed from the air by wet and dry deposition(SRC). Benz(a)anthracene irradiated with light at wavelengths greater than 290 nm was found to be 25.3 percent degraded after 17 hours(4). Benz(a)anthracene is found in the atmosphere both as the free vapor and adsorbed to particulate matter. Polyaromatic hydrocarbons are found concentrated in submicron particles and aerosols. These particles will be transported but are subject to gravitational settling and scavenging by rain and snow. The estimated half-lives of these particles in the atmosphere has been estimated to be 5 to 30 days during which time they can be transported to remote regions(5,6).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental biodegradation for this compound. Biodegradation is the breakdown of organic matter by microorganisms, such as bacteria and fungi.  An important measure of biodegradability of wastewater is the biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), which is the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) needed (i.e. demanded) by aerobic biological organisms to break down organic material present in a given water sample at certain temperature over a specific time period.

Reference: (1) Freitag D et al; pp. 111-36 in QSAR Environ Toxicol Proc Workshop Quant Struct Act Relat. Kaiser KLE, ed. Dordrecht, Netherlands: Reidell (1984)
(2) Malaney GW et al; J Water Pollut Control Red 39: 2020-29 (1967)
(3) Verschueren K; Handbook of Environmental Data on Organic Chemicals. New York, NY: Van Nostrand Reinhold p. 269 (1996)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: Benz(a)anthracene, at a concentration of 0.05 ppm in the presence of 50 ug/L activated sludge, produced <0.1 percent carbon dioxide in 5 days(1). A biodegradation study of benz(a)anthracene, based on theoretical biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) measurements, using an Ashland City activated sludge seed (2,500 mg/L), a Nashville activated sludge seed (2,500 mg/L) and a Franklin sludge seed (2,500 mg/L) and an initial concentration of 500 mg/L benz(a)anthracene, achieved 0.3, 2.1, and 1.6 percent of its theoretical BOD, respectively, after 144 hours; using an Ashland City activated sludge seed (5,000 mg/L), a Nashville activated sludge seed (5,000 mg/L) and a Franklin sludge seed (5,000 mg/L) and an initial concentration of 500 mg/L benz(a)anthracene, benz(a)anthracene achieved 1.0, 1.0, and 5.4 percent of its theoretical BOD, respectively, after 144 hours(2). No biodegradation of benz(a)anthracene (initial concentration 10 ug/L) to carbon dioxide in estuarine water was observed after an incubation period of 48 hours(3).

Reference: (1) Cerniglia CE; Rev Biochem Toxicol 3: 321-61 (1988)
(2) Cerniglia CE; Biodegradation 3: 351-68 (1992)
(3) Cerniglia CE et al; Appl Environ Microb60: 3931-38 (1994)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: Studies have shown that the microorganism Beijerinckia sp., strain B-836, oxidized benz(a)anthracene to four dihydrodiols, the major isomer being cis-1,2-dihydroxyl-1,2-dihydrobenz(a)anthracene (1). Other studies have shown that cells of Cunninghamella elegans grown in the presence of benz(a)anthracene formed trans-8,9-dihydroxy-8,9-dihydrobenz(a)anthracene (90 percent), trans-10,11-dihydroxy-10,11-dihydrobenz(a)anthracene (6 percent) and a trace amount of trans-3,4-dihydroxy-3,4-dihydrobenz(a)anthracene (4 percent)(3). Metabolites produced from benz(a)anthracene by unidentified fungi include benz(a)anthracene trans-3,4-dihydrodiol, benz(a)anthracene trans-8,9-dihydrodiol, benz(a)anthracene trans-10,11-dihydrodiol, phenolic and tetrahydroxy derivatives of benz(a)anthracene, glucuronide and sulfate conjugates(2).

Reference: (1) Gibson DT et al; Science 189: 295-7 (1975)
(2) Groenewegen D, Stolp H; Zentrabl Bakteriol Parasitenkd Infektionskr Hyg Abt 1: Orig Reihe B 162: 225-32 (1976)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: There is evidence that bacteria and fungi exist in the environment that degrade benz(a)anthracene(1-3,11). Several researchers have studied the degradation in sediment which has been contaminated with petroleum products. In one such study, 1.4-1.8% degradation of benz(a)anthracene was observed per week in a seawater-sediment slurry which indicates a half-life of 199-252 days(4,5). Another study determined a half-life for benz(a)anthracene of 290 days in sediment from an oil-contaminated stream but a half-life of 10 to 400 times as long in an uncontaminated stream(8). Microbial degradation of benz(a)anthracene is faster in the upper layers of sediment(4). Another investigator reported a much faster half-life for benz(a)anthracene, 9 days in stream sediment near the outfall of a coal-coking operation but no degradation in the stream water(6). Another study reported no degradation of benz(a)anthracene in an estuarine stream(7). In some situations, degradation of benz(a)anthracene was limited by lack of nutrients in the water(9,10).

Reference: Lee RF et al; Environ Sci Technol 12 (7): 832-8 (1978)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: Prudhoe crude oil enriched with polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) was added as dispersion to controlled ecosystem enclosures suspended in Saanich Inlet, Canada. Concentration of various PAH were determined in water, zooplankton, oysters and bottom sediments. Initial concentration of benz(a)anthracene, benzo(a)pyrene, and fluoranthene ranged from 1-6 ug/L. Concentration decreases at an exponential rate due to ... microbial degradation and sedimentation.

StringWithMarkup.String: The rate constant for the vapor-phase reaction of benz(a)anthracene with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals has been estimated as 5.0X10-11 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(SRC) using a structure estimation method(1). This corresponds to an atmospheric half-life of about 8 hours at an atmospheric concentration of 5X10+5 hydroxyl radicals per cu cm(1). Benz(a)anthracene is not expected to undergo hydrolysis in the environment due to the lack of functional groups that hydrolyze under environmental conditions(2). Benz(a)anthracene irradiated with light at wavelengths greater than 290 nm was found to be 25.3 percent degraded after 17 hours(3). The rate of decomposition of benz(a)anthracene adsorbed on the surface of kaolin particulates after irradiation to sunlight and UV light was determined to be 0.142/hour yielding 7,12-benzanthraquinone(4). Degradation products of benz(a)anthracene irradiated for 6 hours using a mercury lamp at wavelengths > 290 include p-quinones, dialdehydes, hydroxy derivatives, and coumarines/xanthones(5). Exposure of benz(a)anthracene to nitrogen dioxide and ozone at varying levels for 6 hours showed degradation of benz(a)anthracene ranging from 0 to 47 percent(6). The photolysis half-life of benz(a)anthracene in pure water exposed to sunlight for a maximum of 75 minutes was determined to be 0.67 hours(7).

Reference: (1) Mill T et al; Chemosphere 10: 1281-90 (1981)

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental bioconcentration for this compound.  Bioconcentration is the accumulation of a chemical in or on an organism when the source of chemical is solely water. Bioconcentration is a term that was created for use in the field of aquatic toxicology. Bioconcentration can also be defined as the process by which a chemical concentration in an aquatic organism exceeds that in water as a result of exposure to a waterborne chemical.

StringWithMarkup.String: The log bioaccumulation factor for benz(a)anthracene in lake trout (Salvelinus namaycush) obtained from Lake Superior was 3.98(1). An estimated BCF of 2,940 was calculated in fish for benz(a)anthracene (SRC), using a measured log Kow of 5.76(2) and a regression-derived equation(3). According to a classification scheme(4), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is very high(SRC), provided the compound is not metabolized by the organism(SRC).

StringWithMarkup.String: The bioaccumulation factor of benz(a)anthracene in activated sludge, calculated as the concentration of chemical in sludge (ug/g) divided by the final concentration of chemical in water (ug/g), was determined to be 24,400 after 5 days; the bioaccumulation factor of benz(a)anthracene in algae (Chlorella fusca), calculated as the concentration of chemical in algae (ug/g) divided by the final concentration of chemical in water (ug/g), was determined to be 3,180 after 1 day; the bioaccumulation factor of benz(a)anthracene in golden ide fish (Leuciscus idus melanotus), calculated as the concentration of chemical in fish (ug/g) divided by the median concentration of chemical in water (ug/g), was determined to be 350 after 3 days(1). The average accumulation of benz(a)anthracene in sediment and worms after incubation for 42 days was determined to be 29.9 and 19.4 ng/g dry weight(2). Benz(a)anthracene, having a maximum exposure concentration of 0.005 ppm, was determined to bioconcentrate in the marine species Crassostrea virginica at a level of 2.8 ppm after 2 days. This yielded a bioconcentration factor of 560; benz(a)anthracene, having a maximum exposure concentration of 0.0001 ppm, was determined to bioconcentrate in the marine species Crassostrea virginica at a level of 1.8 ppm after 8 days. This yielded a bioconcentration factor of 18,000(3). The bioconcentration factor for benz(a)anthracene in the Daphnid Pulex was determined to be 10,000(4). The half-life of benz(a)anthracene in the oyster, mussel, and clam averaged 11.2, 11.05, and 4.0 days, respectively(5).

Section.Description: Sorption to soils and sediments is an important factor on the transport and fate of organic contaminants in the environment.  The soil/water adsorption coefficient, also known as solid-water distribution coefficient (Kd), measures the amount of chemical substance adsorbed onto soil per amount of water.  Since adsorption occurs predominantly by partition into the soil organic matter, it is more useful to normalize the Kd value to the organic carbon content of a soil and express the distribution coefficient in Koc (organic carbon normalized distribution coefficient).  The greater the Kd (or Koc) value, the less likely a chemical will leach or contribute to runoff.  A very high value means it is strongly adsorbed onto soil and organic matter and does not move throughout the soil.

Reference: (1) Smith JH et al; Environmental Pathways of Selected Chemicals in the Aquatic Environment. Part II Laboratory studies. USEPA 600/7-78-074 pp. 39-63 (1978)
(2) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 23 (1983)
(3) Lee RF et al; Environ Sci Technol 12: 832-8 (1978)
(4) Hinga KR et al; Environ Sci Technol 14: 1136-43 (1980)
(5) Weisenfels WD et al; Appl Microbio Biotechnol 36: 689-96 (1992)
(6) Verschueren K; Handbook of Environmental Data on Organic Chemicals. New York, NY: Van Nostrand Reinhold p. 269 (1996)

StringWithMarkup.String: Benz(a)anthracene was determined to strongly adsorb to sediment with a Koc range of 545,000 to 1,870,000 in Coyote Creek sediment, Des Moines River sediment, and Searsville Pond sediment(1). According to a recommended classification scheme(2), these experimental Koc values suggest that benz(a)anthracene is expected to be immobile in soil(SRC). In a modeling study, 55, 71 and 88 percent of the benz(a)anthracene was predicted to be sorbed in a lake, stream, and eutrophic pond respectively(1). 39 percent of the benz(a)anthracene added to the water column of a controlled ecosystem was recovered in the sediment a week later(3). Benz(a)anthracene, which adsorbed to sediments in a microcosm, was mostly (40 to 60 percent) found in surface sections collected 4 to 5 cm below the surface(4). Sandy soil from a former wood impregnation plant and heterogeneous soil from a former tar-oil refinery were found to adsorb 105.8 and 95.7 mg/kg soil benz(a)anthracene, respectively(5). In estuarine water, 53 percent benz(a)anthracene adsorbed on particles after 3 hours. After 3 hours incubation in natural seawater, 59 percent of 3 ug/L was taken up by suspended aggregates of dead phytoplankton cells and bacteria(6).

Section.Description: Volatilization of chemicals from water/soil is the transfer of the chemical as a gas through the water-air or soil-air interface under environmental conditions

StringWithMarkup.String: The Henry's Law constant for benz(a)anthracene is 1.2X10-5 atm-cu m/mole(1). This Henry's Law constant indicates that benz(a)anthracene is expected to volatilize from water surfaces(2). Based on this Henry's Law constant, the volatilization half-life from a model river (1 m deep, flowing 1 m/sec, wind velocity of 3 m/sec)(2) is estimated as 3 days(SRC). The volatilization half-life from a model lake (1 m deep, flowing 0.05 m/sec, wind velocity of 0.5 m/sec)(2) is estimated as 39 days(SRC). Benz(a)anthracene 's Henry's Law constant indicates that volatilization from moist soil surfaces may occur(SRC). In a laboratory experiment using a beaker, the volatilization half-life of benz(a)anthracene in a rapidly-stirred aqueous solution was determined to be 89 hours(3). However, adsorption is expected to attenuate the rate of volatilization from water and moist soils(SRC). The volatilization half-life from a model pond was estimated as 12 years when adsorption was considered(4). Benz(a)anthracene is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces(SRC) based on a vapor pressure of 2.1X10-7 mm Hg at 25 °C Hg(5).

StringWithMarkup.String: GROUNDWATER: Well water samples collected on September 9, 1980 were found to contain an average benz(a)anthracene concn of 10.8 ug/L(1). Nineteen cities across the United States participated in a Nationwide Urban Runoff Program from 1978 to 1982. Benz(a)anthracene had a 4 percent frequency detection, being detected in Lake Quinsigamond, MA and Bellevue WA(2). Utility right-of-way ditches flowing into salmon streams in the Lower Mainland and Vancouver Island of British Columbia, Canada were sampled in 1990 and 1991. Benz(a)anthracene concentrations in ditch water ranged from 0.12 to 6.1 ug/L(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: DRINKING WATER: In the heavily industrialized area of Kitakyushu, Japan, benz(a)anthracene was not detected in tap water(1). A sample from Ottawa, Canada contained 3.3 parts/trillion benz(a)anthracene(2). Four out of five samples of Nordic (Finland, Norway, Sweden) tap water contained 0.12 to 1.5 parts/trillion benz(a)anthracene(3). Benz(a)anthracene concentrations of German drinking water samples ranged from 1 to 23.2 parts/trillion(4). Benz(a)anthracene was detected at mean concentrations of 2.5 to 92.4 ng/L in drinking water from 3 metropolitan areas of Taiwan(5).

Reference: (1) Cripps GC; Marine Poll Bull 24: 109-14 (1992)
(2) DeLeon IR et al; Chemosphere 15: 795-805 (1986)

(4) Ardag H et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 86: 221-225 (2011)
(5) Qiao M et al; Sci Total Environ 481:178-185 (2014)

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: Benz(a)anthracene was detected in uncontaminated seawater of Atlantic sector the Southern Antarctic Ocean at an average concentration of 0.9 ng/L(1). Water samples were collected at 11 different locations along the length of the Mississippi River in the summer of 1984. Benz(a)anthracene was detected at stations 6 (near Cairo, IL) and 7 (near Memphis, TN) with concentrations of 4 and 5 parts/trillion, respectively(2). Benz(a)anthracene levels in eight stations located in the Guanabara Bay Basin, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, sampled from September 2011 to August 2012 were in the low ng/L range(3). Benz(a)anthracene was detected at 4 out of 8 monitoring stations in water samples collected in the Menderes River, Turkey at average levels of 0.2 to 0.4 ug/L(4). Benz(a)anthracene was detected at several sampling locations in the Haihe River System, China in the sub ug/L range (dissolved) and low ug/g range (suspended solids)(5).

Reference: (1) Luenberger C et al; Atmos Environ 22: 695-705 (1988)
(2) Gouin T et al; Atmos Pollut Res 1: 9-15 (2010)

StringWithMarkup.String: RAIN/SNOW: Snow, rain, and fog samples were collected near the Swiss Federal Institute for Water Resources and Water Pollution Control (EAWAG) near Zurich, Switzerland, dates unknown(1). The mean concentration of benz(a)anthracene in the dissolved and particulate phases for snow was determined to be 9.6 and 21 ng/L, respectively; the mean concentration of benz(a)anthracene in the dissolved and particulate phases for rain was determined to be 2.4 and 3.6 ng/L, respectively; the mean concentration of benz(a)anthracene in the particulate phase for fog was determined to be 190 ng/L(1) The mean concentration of benz(a)anthracene in snow samples from Fairbanks, Alaska was 3.7 ng/L (snowpack) and 2080 ng/L (snow dump)(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: An investigation was conducted from June 1988 to March 1989 at the Sydney Steel Corporation, Sydney, Nova Scotia where benz(a)anthracene was detected at levels of 105 ppm, 51,700 ppm, and 13.9 ppm in coal tar, DNAPL (dense non-aqueous phase liquid), and LNAPL (light non-aqueous phase liquid), respectively(1). Suspended particulate matter samples were collected in exhaust rooms of the tunnel running under the Patapsco River in Baltimore, MD from 1985 to 1986. Benz(a)anthracene in the tunnel had a lower average concentration ranging from 1.9 to 29 ng/cu-m as opposed to the average benz(a)anthracene concentration in 1975 of 102 ng/cu-m(2). The open burning of rubber tires yielded 82 mg/kg chunk tire and 102 mg/kg shred tire of benz(a)anthracene in the tire emissions(3). The concentration of benz(a)anthracene in an effluent channel from a coking plant was determined to be 15 ug/g dry weight in sediment and 2.0 ug/L in water(4). Analysis of several diesel engine emissions revealed an average benz(a)anthracene concentration of 33.0 ug/hr(5). The concentration of benz(a)anthracene in four fuels was determined to average 0.72 mg/L; the concentration of benz(a)anthracene from particulate emission and gaseous emission from a fuel-injected Otto engine was determined to average 2.77 ug/km and 1.81 ug/km, respectively(6). Mean benz(a)anthracene emissions from the top of coke ovens from 4 plants located in China ranged from 0.09 to 11.39 ug/cu m(7).

Reference: (1) Rogge WF et al; Environ Sci Technol 27: 636-51 (1993)
(2) Rogge WF et al; Environ Sci Technol 27: 1892-1904 (1993)
(3) Rogge WF et al; Atmos Environ 27A: 1309-30 (1993)
(4) Rogge WF et al; Environ Sci Technol 27: 2736-44 (1993)

StringWithMarkup.String: Fine aerosol emission rates for benz(a)anthracene from noncatalyst automobiles, catalyst automobiles, and heavy-duty diesel trucks were determined to be 73.8, 1.9, and 3.6 ug/km, respectively(1). Benz(a)anthracene was identified in brake lining particles and road dust particles at concentrations of 1.5 and 1.2 ug/g of particle sample, respectively(2). Aerosol samples were collected systematically throughout a complete annual cycle (1982) at four urban sites in southern California. Ambient annual concentrations of benz(a)anthracene ranged from 0.09 to 0.29 ng/cu m(3). Fine particle emission rates for benz(a)anthracene from a natural gas-fired water heater and a natural gas-fired space heater were determined. A HEPA-filtered dilution air sample emission rate for benz(a)anthracene was not detected; the emission rate for benz(a)anthracene through the first filter was determined to be 497.7 pg/kJ; the emission rate for benz(a)anthracene through the backup filter was 6.7 pg/kJ(4).

Reference: (1) Akiyama T et al; J UOEH 2: 285-300 (1980)
(2) Kveseth K et al; Chemosphere 11: 623-39 (1982)

(3) IARC; Monograph on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk of Chemicals to Humans. Certain Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons and Heterocyclic Compounds.  Lyon, France: International Agency For Research on Cancer Vol. 3: 45-68 (1973)

(5) Verschueren K; Handbook of Environmental Data on Organic Chemicals. New York, NY: Van Nostrand Reinhold Co pp. 269 (1996)

StringWithMarkup.String: Several waste water samples contaminated with possible industrial or bituminous waste ranged from 25 to 10,360 ug/cu-m benz(a)anthracene(3). Industries with raw waste water that reported mean benz(a)anthracene concentrations of >150 ppb: organic chemicals manufacturing/plastics (880 ppb), foundries and iron and steel manufacturing; industries <100 ppb: photographic equipment/supplies, timber products processing, electrical/electronic components, nonferrous metal manufacturing and coil coating(4). In a study conducted in Oslo, Norway, Bikkelaget sewage treatment plant effluent during the dry period reported 27 and 40 parts/trillion benz(a)anthracene in 1979 and 1980, respectively; after rainfall, 58 and 184 parts/trillion benz(a)anthracene was reported in 1979 and 1980, respectively(2). In the industrial Kitakyushu area of Japan, sewage effluent was reported as having a 53 ppb benz(a)anthracene concentration(1). Exhaust from 2-cycle diesel engine was reported as having a benz(a)anthracene concentration of 2.3 to 15 ug/cu-m(3). Emissions from representative European gasoline engines, leaded and unleaded, contained 7.3 to 32.4 ppb benz(a)anthracene; emissions from an asphalt hot mixing plant contained 5 to 24 ng/cu m benz(a)anthracene; coke oven emissions were reported as having 105 to 2740 ppm benz(a)anthracene concentrations(5); cigarette smoke contained 0.3 ug/100 cigarettes of benz(a)anthracene(3,5). Sewage influent from the Kitahyushu area of Japan contained 200 ppb benz(a)anthracene(1). Sewage water from household, trade, road, and industrial sources contained a maximum benz(a)anthracene concentration of 31.4 ppb(3).

Reference: (1) IARC; Monograph on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk of Chemicals to Humans. Polynuclear Aromatic Compounds, Part 1, Chemical, Environmental, and Experimental Data. Lyon, France: International Agency For Research on Cancer Vol. 32: 135-45 (1983)

StringWithMarkup.String: Benz(a)anthracene was detected in exhaust emissions from gasoline engines (50 to 83 ug/L fuel); emissions from burnt coals (0.04 to 9.4 mg/kg)(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: The concentration of benz(a)anthracene in bed sediments and suspended sediments collected from the Suisun Bay, California averaged 16.8 and 51.5 ng/g dry weight, respectively(1). The concentration of benz(a)anthracene in sediment trap fluxes collected from Lake Superior from 1984 to 1985 averaged 41.4 ng/g in surficial sediments, 58 ng/g in surface water sediment traps, and 64 ng/g in surface water suspended solids(2). The concentration of benz(a)anthracene in surface sediments collected from the Elizabeth River near Norfolk, VA from April 23 to 27, 1981 yielded an average benz(a)anthracene concentration of 11 ug/g dry weight(3). Bottom sediments collected in the vicinity of a multi-well platform offshore of Matagorda, TX from May 1982 to Nov 1985 had an average benz(a)anthracene concentration of 17.4 ppb(4).

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Worldwide sediment samples (marine and freshwater) were from not detected to 21,000 ppb (benz(a)anthracene was not distinguished from chrysene and triphenylene)(1). It was observed that total concentrations of PAH from the Northeast US were much higher than in other areas(1). Hersey River near Read City, MI, spring fed contamination from the site of a former wood preservation facility where 2 known creosote spills had occurred (15,000 and 18,000 gals), sampling site upstream from entry point - not detected, 8 sampling sites downstream (up to 5 km) - 1,349 ppb (site 2) to 31 ppb (site 8)(2). 2 remote lakes in the Adirondack Park, NY - Woods lake, surface 360 ppb, 80-84 cm depth - 1 ppb, Sagamore Lake, surface 78 ppb, 4-8 cm depth - 89 ppb, 80-84 cm depth - 1 ppb, source primarily produced by anthropogenic combustion of fossil fuels(3). Vincent Landing, Calcasieu River, LA - identified, not quantified(4).

Reference: Gschwend PM, Hites RA; Geochim Cosmochim Acta 45 (12): 2359-76 (1981)

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) measured in dated sediment cores from several sites in northeastern USA (Lake Superior, Isle Royale, Somes Sound, Hadlock Lower Pond, Coburn Mountain Pond & outer Boston Harbor). Fluxes of 10 PAHs were measured at each site the periods roughly corresponding to the present, 1950 & 1900. Remote sites consistently showed present-day deliveries of individual PAHs near 1 ng/square cm/yr, probably reflecting atmospheric fallout of these combustion-derived pollutants. Sites nearer urban centers showed greater current inputs (avg of 35 ng/square cm/yr), presumably caused by greater fallout of PAH-laden particulate matter near their origin. /PAH/

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Benz(a)anthracene concentrations were reported as folloews: 2 New England area sites - Atlantic Ocean shelf 3.6 to 6.1 ppb, Buzzards Bay, MA - 330 ppb (0.15 mi from shore) and 41 ppb (1.3 mi from shore)(1,2). StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: Avg 1965 US urban concentrations approximately 4 ng/cu m(1,3), with an avg range of 0.18 to 4.6 ng/cu m(5). Detroit, MI had a range of 0.4 to 21.6 ng/cu m (3 sites, 20 samples), New York City (4 sites, 47 samples) - 0.1 to 16 ng/cu m(1). Cleveland, OH had a maximum value of 140 ng/cu m (448 values)(3). Representative European metropolitan areas not detected to 29 ng/cu m, measurements taken from 1968 to 1975(1,2,3). Osaka City Japan, vapor phase - 0.56 to 11.0 ng/cu m, particulate phase 0.95 to 23.7 ng/cu m however BA was not separable from chrysene and triphenylene(4). Benz(a)anthracene was detected in ambient air at 8 locations of the US in 2016 according to data contained in the EPA Air Quality System (AQS) database (6). The arithmetic means ranged from 0.012 to 0.33 ng/cu m at these 8 locations(6). Benz(a)anthracene was identified in 9 percent of air samples obtained near the Arizona-Mexico border(7). Benz(a)anthracene was detected in the air of Singapore at levels of 0.02 to 2.4 ng/cu m (particle phase) and 0.91 to 21.6 ng/cu m (gas phase) in sampling conducted in June 2007 and May 2008(8). The geometric mean concentration of benz(a)anthracene in Birmingham and London, UK was 0.10 and 0.06 ng/cu m, respectively and the geometric mean concentration was 0.07 ng/cu m in a suburban area of the UK(9). The mean concentration of benz(a)anthracene in Beijing, China during the 2008 Olympic games was 0.3742 ng/cu m during source control periods and 0.9565 ng/cu m during non source control periods (10).

StringWithMarkup.String: Benz(a)anthracene has been identified in many food sources (ug/kg): smoked beef (chipped), 0.4; smoked ham, 2.8; barbecued beef, 13.2; smoked hot sausage, 0.5; smoked frankfurters, 1.5; smoked salami, 1.5, pepperoni, 0.2; charcoal-broiled steak, 1.0; charcoal-broiled hamburger, 50.0; charcoal-broiled frankfurter, 2.0; vegetable oils, 0.8 to 1.1; spinach, 16; kale, 43 to 230; cereals, 0.4 to 6.8; very dark roast coffee, 2; soots, 16 to 150; and Japanese horse mackerel, gas broiler, 0.6 to 2.9(1). The concentration of benz(a)anthracene in lettuce and rye grown at varying distances from a highway in Sweden were determined to range from 0.4 to 1.9 ug/kg fresh weight and 0.2 ug/kg fresh weight, respectively(2). The fine aerosol emission rate for benz(a)anthracene from a frying hamburger (extralean/regular), from a charbroiled hamburger (extralean), and from a charbroiled hamburger (regular) was determined to be 0.02, 0.30, and 0.29 mg/kg, respectively(3). Benz(a)anthracene was identified in bolted wheat flour, bolted rye flour, rolled oats, milled oats, milled wheat, and bran in concentrations of <0.1, 0.1, 0.2, <0.1, <0.1, and 11 ug/kg, respectively(4). The concentration of benz(a)anthracene in bread and margarine was determined to be 0.2 and 5.8 ug/kg, respectively(5).

Reference: (1) IARC; Monograph on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk of Chemicals to Humans. Polynuclear Aromatic Compounds, Part 1, Chemical, Environmental, and Experimental Data. Lyon, France: International Agency For Research on Cancer Vol. 32: 135-45 (1983)

StringWithMarkup.String: The concentration of benz(a)anthracene/chyrsene found composite fish samples collected from Great Lakes harbors and tributaries between 1980 and 1981 ranged from <0.02 mg/kg to 0.64 mg/kg(1). Benz(a)anthracene was detected in approximately 5 percent of fish samples (0.3 ug/kg dry weight) collected during April 1992 along the western coast of the Gulf of Kuwait(2). The concentration of benz(a)anthracene in shellfish from Miyagi Prefecture, Japan was determined to be 1.62 ppm in mussels, 1.13 ppm in oysters, 1.11 ppm in corb-shells, and 1.34 ppm in short-necked clams(3). The concentration of benz(a)anthracene in vertebrate fish tissue obtained from the US Fisheries and Wildlife Service, Columbia, MO was determined to average 12 ppb(4). Benz(a)anthracene was detected in bivalves at 16 sites of the Tatsushiro Sea, Japan at levels of 0.17 to 23 ng/g(5). Benz(a)anthracene was detected in mussels collected from polluted regions of Mokpo Bay, Korea at 0.013 mg/kg, but was not detected in mussels collected from unpolluted areas(6).

The concentration of benz(a)anthracene in the Asian clam Potamocorbula amurensis collected from the Suisun Bay, California averaged 41.5 ng/g dry weight(2). Levels of benz(a)anthracene in the digestive gland and tail muscle following a three month exposure to creosoted timbers ranged form 2,000 to 20,000 ng/g wet weight and 100 to 560 ng/g wet weight(3). The concentration of benz(a)anthracene in mussels was determined to be 16.5 ug/kg(4).

StringWithMarkup.String: Limestone and weathering crusts were studied at the major cathedrals of Sevilla, Spain, and Mechelan, Belgium; benz(a)anthracene was identified (but not quantified) in both cathedrals at less than 25 percent of the total compounds identified(1). Benz(a)anthracene occurs ubiquitously in products of incomplete combustion. StringWithMarkup.String: OBJECTIVES: To characterize temperature-dependent emissions from paving and built-up roofing asphalt (BURA) and to quantify differences in temperature-related concentrations and composition. METHODS: Using headspace gas chromatography, 18 polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) emission concentrations were quantified over eight temperatures (120-315 °C) for paving asphalt (n = 20) and Types II, III, and IV BURA (n = 5) and were summarized by geometric means (GMs) and geometric standard deviations (GSDs) at each temperature. The relationships between temperature and concentration were evaluated for PAH analytes using mixed-effects regression models. Temperature was categorized into regimes: Regime 1 (120-150 °C) representing temperatures typical of paving asphalt application, Regime 2 (180-230 °C) representing temperatures typical of BURA application, and Regime 3 (260-315 °C) which were high temperatures outside typical application temperatures. An interaction term was used to evaluate differential effects of temperature on paving asphalt versus BURA. RESULTS: In the paving regime (120-150 °C), paving asphalt emission concentrations were highest for 2- and 3-ring PAHs [GM (GSD) at 150 °C of 4.51 (2.07), 3.77 (1.63), 2.26 (1.53), and 1.80 (1.66) ug/cu m for 2-methyl naphthalene, naphthalene, phenanthrene, and acenaphthene, respectively], with all the 4- and 5- to 6-ring individual PAHs mean concentrations below the detection limit, with the exception of benz[a]anthracene. In the BURA regime (180-230 °C), BURA emission concentrations were highest for 2- and 3-ring PAHs [GM (GSD) at 205 °C of 121.3 (1.37), 99.5 (1.31), 69.5 (1.32), and 68.1 (1.37) ug/cu m for acenaphthene, anthracene, 2-methyl naphthalene, and phenanthrene, respectively], with lower but detectable concentrations for 4- and 5- to 6-ring PAHs. For both paving asphalt and BURA, concentrations increased log linearly with temperature. At a given temperature, the highest concentrations were observed for 2-ring PAHs with lower and decreasing concentrations observed with increased ring size. Temperature was a statistically significant (P < 0.01) predictor of concentration for each analyte. Furthermore, the categorical temperature regime variable explained a large percent of the variability in concentrations accounting for 74-92% of the total variability in PAH concentration. In both paving asphalt and BURA, the relationship between temperature and concentration was non-linear. There was a statistically significant difference between paving asphalt and BURA in the temperature-concentration relationship for the each analyte. Temperature alone did not account for differences in paving asphalt and BURA concentrations in 5- to 6-ring PAHs. CONCLUSIONS: Emission concentrations are driven by temperature for both paving asphalt and BURA samples under studied experimental conditions. There are differences in paving asphalt and BURA emission concentrations that are not explained by temperature alone; concentrations were higher and consisted of larger ring (4 and 5 to 6) PAHs for BURA as compared to paving asphalt at the respective application temperature ranges.

Reference: (1) IARC; Monograph on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk of Chemicals to Humans. Polynuclear Aromatic Compounds, Part 1, Chemical, Environmental, and Experimental Data. Lyon, France: International Agency For Research on Cancer Vol. 32: 135-45 (1983)
(2) Materna BL et al; Am Ind Hyg Assoc J 53: 69-76 (1992)

StringWithMarkup.String: Benz(a)anthracene is present as a major component of total content of polynuclear aromatic hydrocarbon compounds in the environment. Human exposure to benz(a)anthracene occurs primarily through smoking of tobacco, inhalation of polluted air and by ingestion of food and water contaminated by combustion effluents(1). Industrial hygiene measure of exposures to wild-land fire fighters was conducted in northern California during three consecutive fire seasons (1986 to 1989). Results revealed that the average exposure to 95 percent of the fire fighters was 0.018 ug/cu-m benz(a)anthracene(1).

Reference: (1) Bjoerseth A et al; Scan J Work Environ Health 4: 212-23 (1978)
(2) Bjoerseth A et al; Scand J Work, Environ Health 4 (3): 224-36 (1978)
(3) Gammage RB; pp 653-707 in Handbook of Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons. A Bjoerseth, ed. New York, NY: Marcel Dekker Inc (1983)
(4) Nordholm L et al; Scan J Work Environ Health 12: 614-18 (1986)
(5) Gustafson P et al; Environ Sci Technol 42: 5074-5080 (2008)

StringWithMarkup.String: Benz(a)anthracene was identified in a Soderberg, Norway anode plant, a prebaked aluminum reduction plant and vertical pin plant. Benz(a)anthracene particulate levels in the atmosphere ranged from 0.10 to 1.0 ug/cu m in the anode plant, 0.08 to 0.18 ug/cu m in the aluminum plant, and 0.06 to 6.3 ug/cu m at the pin plant(1). Glass capillary gas chromatography showed that workers in coke plant were exposed to 5 to 1000 mg polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH)/cu m air (including fluoranthene). Fluoranthene was present at approximately 30% of the total polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH). Particulate matter contains 98% respirable PAH(2). The percent benz(a)anthracene of the total polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons identified in various work atmospheres was determined to be approximately 2.5 in a ferro-alloy plant, 7 in an aluminum plant, 9 in an iron works plant, 12 in a coke plant, and <0.1 in a foundry(3). The level of exposure to polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons from smoking kilns in Danish smokehouses was determined. The maximum benz(a)anthracene concentration observed in 10 smokehouses was determined to be 92 ug/cu m(4). Benz(a)anthracene was detected in 8 out of 13 Swedish homes that used wood heating appliances at levels of <LOQ to 2.5 ng/cu m, and it was detected in 2 homes that did not use wood heating appliances atlevels <LOQ to 0.55 ng/cu m(5).

StringWithMarkup.String: The study was conducted in a Chinese population with occupational or environmental exposures to polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). A total of 106 subjects were recruited from coke-oven workers (workers), residents in a metropolitan area (residents) and suburban gardeners (gardeners). All subjects were monitored twice for their personal exposures to PAHs. The biological samples were collected for measurements of 1-hydroxypyrene (1-OHP) and cotinine in urine. The geometric means of personal exposure levels of pyrene, benz(a)anthracene (BaA) and benzo(a)pyrene (BaP) in workers were 1.470, 0.978 and 0.805 ug/cu m, respectively. The corresponding levels in residents were 0.050, 0.034 and 0.025 ug/cu m; and those in gardeners were 0.011, 0.020 and 0.008 ug/cu m, respectively. The conjugate of 1-OHP with glucuronide (1-OHP-G) is the predominant form of pyrene metabolite in urine and it showed strong associations with exposures not only to pyrene, but also to BaA, BaP and total PAHs. Most importantly, a significant difference in 1-OHP-G was even detected between the subgroups with exposures to BaP at < 0.010 and > 0.010 but < 0.020 ug/cu m, suggesting that 1-OHP-G is a good marker that can be used for the risk assessment of BaP exposure at levels currently encountered in ambient air. Furthermore, multiple regression analyses of 1-OHP-G on PAHs exposure indicated that cigarette smoke was a major confounding factor and should be considered and adjusted for while using 1-OHP to estimate PAHs exposure.

Reference.Name: EPA SRS List Classification
Reference.Description: Substance Registry Services (SRS) is the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) central system for information about substances that are tracked or regulated by EPA or other sources. It is a resource for basic information about chemicals, biological organisms, and other substances of interest to EPA and its state and tribal partners. SRS makes it possible to identify which EPA data systems, environmental statutes, or other sources have information about a substance and which synonym is used by that system or statute.

Reference.Name: EPA TSCA Classification
Reference.Description:
EPA Chemicals under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) collection contains information on chemicals and their regulation under TSCA. The chemical classification tree is created based on the TSCA substance regulatory flag, UVCB, and commercial activity status.
Update: 2024-12-06 12:51:01

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
Reference.LicenseNote: CC-BY 4.0

Reference.Name: SID 403032468
Reference.Description: The PATENTSCOPE database from WIPO includes patent and chemical structure search (with a free account) that gives access to millions of patent documents. The World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO) is a specialized United Nations (UN) agency headquartered in Geneva (Switzerland). Our mission is to lead the development of a balanced and effective international Intellectual Property (IP) system that enables innovation and creativity for the benefit of all. We help governments, businesses and society realize the benefits of Intellectual Property and are notably a world reference source for IP information.
